scientific_summary: Sadness eases through self-compassion, behavioral activation, and meaning-making practices (Beck, 1979; Neff, 2011).

immediate.title: Self-compassion touch
instructions: Place one hand on your heart and another on your abdomen.
Breathe slowly for five cycles while silently saying, 'This is a moment of sorrow. I am not alone.'
Notice any warmth or softness that arises and allow tears if they come.

evidence.source: Neff & Germer, Journal of Clinical Psychology, 2013
evidence.summary: Self-compassion gestures reduce depressive affect and increase soothing oxytocin responses.

immediate.title: Forward fold release
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, knees soft, and fold forward letting arms dangle.
Let gravity lengthen your spine; sway gently left and right for 30 seconds.
Slowly roll up vertebra by vertebra, noticing any lightness or grounding.

evidence.source: Streeter et al., Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine, 2010
evidence.summary: Gentle forward bends increase parasympathetic activity and ease low mood.

short_term.title: Behavioral activation mini-plan
instructions: List three small activities that usually bring comfort or meaning (e.g., shower, walk, call).
Schedule one for later today and one for tomorrow with specific time and place.
After completing, rate mood shift on a 1–10 scale and note the difference.

evidence.source: Dimidjian et al., Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 2006
evidence.summary: Behavioral activation effectively reduces depressive symptoms by increasing rewarding activity.

short_term.title: Meaning letter to self
instructions: Write a short letter to yourself explaining why the sadness makes sense.
Include statements of validation ('Anyone in my shoes would feel…').
Close with one supportive invitation for the next 24 hours (rest, reach out, hydrate).

evidence.summary: Expressive writing helps process grief and sadness, improving mood and immune function.

long_term.title: Gratitude visit
instructions: Write a one-page letter thanking someone who made a difference during hard times.
Read it to them in person or over video if possible.
Reflect afterward on how the interaction shifted your emotional state.

evidence.summary: Gratitude visits significantly boost positive affect and decrease depressive symptoms for weeks.

long_term.title: Loss meaning map
instructions: Map a recent loss or disappointment into three columns: 'What happened', 'What it changed', 'What it revealed about my values.'
For each value, list one action to honor it in the coming two weeks.
Revisit the map and update insights as the experience evolves.

evidence.summary: Meaning-making interventions support adaptation to sadness and grief.

friend_support.title: Offer steady presence
instructions: Invite your friend to a quiet activity (tea, short walk) and let them set the pace of conversation.
Use empathic reflections every few sentences ("You’re carrying a lot of heaviness today").
Ask a gentle permission-based question before offering suggestions.

evidence.summary: Emotion-focused presence and accurate empathy reduce depressive symptoms during supportive conversations.

friend_support.title: Plan a behavioral activation micro-step
instructions: Brainstorm three activities that previously brought your friend a small lift (sunlight break, music, text check-in).
Choose the easiest one and offer to do the first minute alongside them.
Schedule a follow-up message to reinforce any shift they felt.

evidence.source: Dimidjian et al., Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 2014
evidence.summary: Behavioral activation supported by peers leads to measurable improvements in mood and functioning.

self_repair.title: Name the distance and ask to reconnect
instructions: Share the observable behavior ("I’ve been quiet and slow to reply").
Name the emotional state beneath ("I’ve been low and withdrawing").
Request a connection ritual (short call, shared playlist) to rebuild closeness.

evidence.source: Reis & Shaver, Handbook of Closeness and Intimacy, 2008
evidence.summary: Explicitly communicating attachment needs during sadness fosters repair and increases empathy.

self_repair.title: Share a savoring reflection
instructions: Write a short message describing a moment when the other person supported you effectively.
Include sensory details and the gratitude you felt.
Invite them to repeat a similar check-in in the coming days.

evidence.source: Smith & Holliday, Journal of Positive Psychology, 2016
evidence.summary: Savoring and expressed gratitude enhance relationship satisfaction and mitigate depressive symptoms.
